answers.answer: Hi.It is possible that most of your symptoms are related to diabetic neuropathy, although other conditions that could be present concomitantly cannot be ruled out at this point.Nortriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant but is commonly used off-label for treatment of neuropathic pain. Other drugs that can be used and might help relieve some of your pain include imipramine, narcotic analgesics such as morphine, anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or gabapentin, and antiarrhythmics.You mentioned being currently part of a clinical study for Bristol Myers. Are you under a nondisclosure agreement with them or can you tell us what drug you are being tested with for diabetes? Before you try alternatives for your pain, you might need to inform the study researchers about your current and planned alternative medications as they may interfere with the study results.Hope this helps. Good luck.

question: I am 44 yr old and have neuropathy in feet.due to diabetes. I am in a clinical study with Bristol Meyers for diabetes and so blood is for the most part under control. BP is 118 over 76, heart is rate is70s to 80s, Cholesteral LDL is 1.71, Triglicerides is high- 6.0 area. I am on Lipidil now at 145 mg and nortriptyline for pain at 25mg. Also Metformine 2000mg per day. First off, How am I doing? Anything else I can do?My pains include foot heat and cold sensitiveness, tingling, pain, balls of foot pain, ankle pain which drives me nuts at night, Also pain in left hip on certain movements, Left shoulder pain on certain movements, Knee pain and the feeling of swelling sometimes, Tennis elbow and arm pain and pain in my hands at certain movements like gripping. I also have diareeha most times. My blood checks and check ups say that my liver is ok, kidneys are not leaking, cardiogram is good and LDL has dropped from 3.70 to 1.71 in the past year. The problem is that I can't seem to lessen the pains and now have gone on to using the Nortriptyline which I have been trying to avoid for over two years now.
